additionalInfo: If you're not using enough ground coffee for the size of your portafilter basket, the brew time will be too quick.

If your coffee beans are ground too coarse, the water can pass through the coffee grounds far too quickly, resulting in an under-extracted coffee. By grinding your coffee finer, it can resist the flow of the hot water more effectively, and slow down your espresso shot time.
When your tamp is too light, it creates inconsistencies in the puck, causing channeling and for the water to run through too quickly.
The hotter the water, the quicker it is to extract compounds such as oils, acids, and caffeine.
If you overfill your machine with coffee, the water will take longer than it should to dispense through the grounds.
If you grind your coffee too fine, the particles will fit too tightly together and prevent water from getting through at an adequate speed.
If your coffee is ground too fine, the water won't be able to get through which will cause your machine to choke and splutter.

When coffee is under-extracted, it can cause a sour taste and lack of body. This flavor profile occurs because the oils arenâ€™t extracted, leaving the coffee without body or sweetness and bitterness to provide balance.

tip: Your grind is the wrong size
additionalInfo: if your shot takes longer than 25 seconds to pull your grind is too fine. If it takes less than 20 seconds to pull, then the grinds are too coarse.
Stale coffee beans have been exposed to oxygen, thus breaking down the oils that give high-quality coffee its flavor.Without those oils, crema cannot be produced.
Try tamping harder to increase the pressure.
